medium: Granular gray-buff ceramic, mineral inclusions, orange-red and brown-black slip decoration
creditline: Gift of William and Mildred F. Kaplan
inscribed: Text in front of maize god: YAX-TSUK/tu-KAB/tu-CH'EEN/K'UH ["it is the first gourd in the earth, in the cave of the god(s)"] (Saturno et al. 2007:33)

texts.textentryhtml: Acquired by William Kaplan by April 1971; gift of William and Mildred F. Kaplan to the Princeton University Art Museum, 1975.

bibliography.boilertext: Michael D. Coe, The Maya Scribe and His World (New York: The Grolier Club, 1973).
bibliography.citation: Michael D. Coe, The Maya Scribe and His World (New York: The Grolier Club, 1973)., cat. no. 43, pp. 94–95 (illus.)

bibliography.boilertext: Michael D. Coe, Lords of the Underworld: Masterpieces of Classic Maya Ceramics (Princeton: Princeton University Art Museum, 1978)
bibliography.citation: Michael D. Coe, Lords of the Underworld: Masterpieces of Classic Maya Ceramics (Princeton: Princeton University Art Museum, 1978), cat. no. 2, pp. 22–27 (illus.)

bibliography.boilertext: Sarah E. Jackson, "Imagining Courtly Communities: An Exploration of Classic Maya Experiences of Status and Identity through Painted Ceramic Vessels," Ancient Mesoamerica 20, no. 1 (Spring, 2009): p. 71-85.
bibliography.citation: Sarah E. Jackson, "Imagining Courtly Communities: An Exploration of Classic Maya Experiences of Status and Identity through Painted Ceramic Vessels," Ancient Mesoamerica 20, no. 1 (Spring, 2009): p. 71-85., fig. 6, pp. 71–85 (illus. rollout line drawing)

bibliography.boilertext: Barbara Kerr and Justin Kerr, "Some Observations on Maya Vase Painters," in Maya Iconography, eds. Elizabeth P. Benson and Gillett G. Griffin (Princeton: Princeton University Press, 1988).
bibliography.citation: Barbara Kerr and Justin Kerr, "Some Observations on Maya Vase Painters," in Maya Iconography, eds. Elizabeth P. Benson and Gillett G. Griffin (Princeton: Princeton University Press, 1988)., fig. 7.2b, 7.6b, and 7.8b, pp. 236–259 (illus.)

bibliography.boilertext: "Acquisitions of the Art Museum 1975," Record of the Art Museum, Princeton University, 35, no. 1 (1976): p. 22-31.
bibliography.citation: "Acquisitions of the Art Museum 1975," Record of the Art Museum, Princeton University, 35, no. 1 (1976): p. 22-31., p. 31

bibliography.boilertext: Francis Robiscek, The Maya Book of the Dead: The Ceramic Codex (Charlottesville: University of Virginia Art Museum, 1981).
bibliography.citation: Francis Robiscek, The Maya Book of the Dead: The Ceramic Codex (Charlottesville: University of Virginia Art Museum, 1981)., Vessel 70 (illus.)

bibliography.boilertext: David Stuart, "Blood Symbolism in Maya Iconography," in Maya Iconography, eds. Elizabeth P. Benson and Gillett G. Griffin (Princeton: Princeton University Press, 1988): 175-221.
bibliography.citation: David Stuart, "Blood Symbolism in Maya Iconography," in Maya Iconography, eds. Elizabeth P. Benson and Gillett G. Griffin (Princeton: Princeton University Press, 1988): 175-221., fig. 5.16, pp. 175–221 (illus.)

bibliography.boilertext: Karl A. Taube, "The Classic Maya Maize God: A Reappraisal," in Fifth Palenque Round Table, 1983, Volume VII, ed. Virginia M. Fields (San Francisco: Pre-Columbian Art Research Institute, 1985): 171-181.
bibliography.citation: Karl A. Taube, "The Classic Maya Maize God: A Reappraisal," in Fifth Palenque Round Table, 1983, Volume VII, ed. Virginia M. Fields (San Francisco: Pre-Columbian Art Research Institute, 1985): 171-181., fig. 2b, pp. 171–181 (illus. line drawing)

exhibitions.citation: The Maya Scribe and His World (April 20–June 5, 1971)

geography.displaygeography: Place made: North America, Guatemala, Petén, Maya area, Nakbé region

caption: Maya ('Codex' style), Late Classic Period, 600–800, Central lowlands, Petén, Maya area, Guatemala, Mesoamerica, Cylinder vase. Granular gray-buff ceramic, mineral inclusions, orange-red and brown-black slip decoration; 12.3 x 12.5 cm. Gift of William and Mildred F. Kaplan (y1975-32)
